channel.title: Debian GNU/kFreeBSD
channel.description:
This is pretty sweet, it is the Frankenstein of Operating Systems. Debian GNU/kFreeBSD is a port of the Debian operating system that consists of the GNU userland, GNU C library, Debian package management (dpkg, apt etc.) and system tools, on top of the FreeBSD kernel.
It is still beta software, but you can download a working livecd called Ging from [url=http://glibc-bsd.alioth.debian.org/ging/]here[/url].
And a guide for actually installing it can be found [url=http://glibc-bsd.alioth.debian.org/doc/index.html]here[/url], I am going to try this in the next few days and tell you how it goes. I am going to install it in VirtualBox first though, just to be on the safe side.
Has anyone actually used this?

item.title: Debian GNU/kFreeBSD
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

ThugLife:

Well i just booted it up on a virtual box and i must say it is pretty nice, i would/could probably use it if i ever decide to leave gentoo.

Did you use Ging or the actual netinst cd?

Mopman:

IIRC, there’s a Debian GNU/Hurd too.

Never knew that, but this kFreeBSD flavor seems like it has more potential.

Read full topic

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

This is pretty sweet, it is the Frankenstein of Operating Systems. Debian GNU/kFreeBSD is a port of the Debian operating system that consists of the GNU userland, GNU C library, Debian package management (dpkg, apt etc.) and system tools, on top of the FreeBSD kernel.

It is still beta software, but you can download a working livecd called Ging from here.

And a guide for actually installing it can be found here, I am going to try this in the next few days and tell you how it goes. I am going to install it in VirtualBox first though, just to be on the safe side.

Has anyone actually used this?
